summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of Florida today entered a final judgment against Miami-Dade County School Board member Jane Doe for her role in an alleged sexual harassment and assault at Carol City High School.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed in federal district court in Miami, Florida, Jane Doe was harassed by two older men who repeatedly asked her to go into the boys' bathroom.  The complaint alleges that Jane Doe, who was a junior in high school at the time, was confronted by one of the men and told that she was in the wrong place at the wrong time.  As alleged in the complaint, Jane alleges that the two men continued to harass her, and Jane was forced to leave class and attend the same off-campus facility for the rest of the day.  Jane's mother confronted Jane about the harassment and told her that she would "have to repeat the whole story again" if a school official or school district employee called her to report the harassment.  In a parallel action, the Florida Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services today announced that it has suspended Jane from participating in student-on-student sexual harassment activities.  Without admitting or denying the allegations, Jane and her mother have consented to the entry of judgments permanently enjoining them from violating the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934 ("Exchange Act") and Rule 10b-5 thereunder, and ordering the school district to pay civil penalties in the amount of $10,000.  Additionally, the district has agreed to pay a civil penalty of $20,000, which will be determined by the court upon motion by the SEC.   The SEC's investigation was conducted by Michael J. Burt and supervised by Jennifer C. Barry of the Miami Regional Office. The SEC appreciates the assistance of the Florida Office of Inspector General, the U. S. Attorney's Office for the Central District, the Federal Bureau of Investigation, and the Department of Education.
